tn.text: The name Levi here refers to the tribe of Levi.

tn.ref: for each leader from his ancestors' tribe

tn.text: The phrase "the covenant decrees" refers to the box that held the tablets that the covenant decrees were written on. AT: "the ark of the covenant" or "the box that holds the covenant decrees" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: the staff of the man whom I choose will bud
tn.text: "buds will start to grow on the staff of the man whom I choose"

tn.ref: cause the complaints from the people of Israel to stop, which they are speaking against you
tn.text: Here "complaints" is an abstract noun that can be expressed as a verb. AT: "make the people of Israel stop complaining against you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: selected from each of the ancestral tribes
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "whom Moses selected from each of the ancestor's tribes" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: the tent of the covenant decrees
tn.text: The phrase "the covenant decrees" refers to the box that held the tablets that the covenant decrees were written on. AT: "the tent of the covenant box" or "the tent that the covenant decrees are in" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
The word "behold" here shows that something especially important has happened. You might have a similar word in your language.

The phrase "the covenant decrees" refers to the box that held the tablets that the covenant decrees were written on. AT: "the ark of the covenant" or "the box that holds the covenant decrees" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: so that you may end complaints against me
tn.text: The word "complaints" is an abstract noun that can be expressed as a verb. AT: "so that you may stop them from complaining against me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
This is what would happen if the people were to continue complaining. God wanted to prevent this. AT: "so that they will not die"

tn.ref: We will die here. We will all perish!
tn.text: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and are combined for emphasis. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
